title: Arthrosamid® Injections: One Shot. Three Years. Zero Surgery.
subtitle: Advanced hydrogel technology that replaces lost cushioning in arthritic knees—delivering lasting relief without pills, steroids, or joint replacement.
summary: Arthrosamid is a non-biodegradable polyacrylamide hydrogel (iPAAG) that integrates into your knee joint to restore shock absorption and reduce pain. Unlike hyaluronic acid (lasts 6 months) or steroids (temporary relief), Arthrosamid provides 3+ years of documented improvement. One injection. One afternoon. Life-changing results.

intro.title: Walk Like You Used To
paragraphs: Knee osteoarthritis doesn't announce itself with drama. It creeps in: stiffness when you stand after sitting. Hesitation before stairs. Avoiding walks you used to love. Then one day you realize—you've been compensating for months, maybe years.

Surgery feels too extreme. Pills mask pain but don't fix anything. Steroid injections wear off in weeks. You're stuck in limbo between 'manageable discomfort' and 'life-altering surgery.' That's where Arthrosamid changes the equation.

This isn't experimental. It's a single-injection hydrogel treatment with 156-week (3-year) clinical trial data showing sustained pain reduction and mobility improvement. This guide explains the science, walks through the London treatment process, and helps you decide if Arthrosamid is right for you.

sections.title: The Technology: What Makes Arthrosamid Different
sections.intro: Most knee injections are temporary Band-Aids. Arthrosamid is permanent infrastructure—like replacing worn suspension in your car.

items.heading: Non-biodegradable hydrogel: The key innovation
items.body: Arthrosamid is made from 97.5% water and 2.5% cross-linked polyacrylamide—the same biocompatible material used safely in medical devices for decades. Unlike hyaluronic acid (which your body breaks down in 6-12 months), Arthrosamid doesn't degrade. It integrates into the synovial membrane lining your joint and stays there, permanently restoring the cushioning your knee has lost.

items.heading: How it actually works inside your knee
items.body: In healthy knees, synovial fluid acts as shock absorber and lubricant. Osteoarthritis reduces fluid volume and viscosity—bone starts grinding on bone. Arthrosamid injects into this space, physically increasing joint cushioning. The hydrogel swells to fill gaps, reducing friction during movement. Your knee essentially gets new suspension. Pain drops. Range of motion improves. Weight-bearing becomes tolerable again.

items.heading: Arthrosamid vs. hyaluronic acid vs. steroids
items.body: Hyaluronic acid (Synvisc, Ostenil): Temporary viscosupplementation lasting 6-12 months. Requires 3-5 injections per course. Repeat annually. Steroids (cortisone): Anti-inflammatory lasting 4-12 weeks. Tissue degradation risk with repeated use. Arthrosamid: Permanent cushioning from single injection. 156-week trial data. No repeat treatments needed. Fundamentally different mechanism and duration.

sections.title: The Treatment Experience: What Actually Happens
sections.intro: From consultation to walking out—here's the realistic timeline and what to expect at each stage.

items.heading: Pre-treatment: Imaging and candidacy (Week 0)
items.body: First, we confirm you're suitable. X-ray or MRI to assess osteoarthritis severity (mild-to-moderate candidates do best). Clinical exam to check range of motion, pain patterns, stability. Discussion of expectations—Arthrosamid reduces pain and improves function, but doesn't reverse bone damage or cure arthritis. If you have severe bone-on-bone disease, we'll discuss joint replacement instead.

items.heading: Injection day: The 30-minute procedure
items.body: Local anesthetic numbs the injection site. Under ultrasound or fluoroscopic guidance, we inject 4ml of Arthrosamid directly into the joint space—same technique as steroid or hyaluronic acid injections. You'll feel pressure, maybe mild discomfort, but not sharp pain. The entire appointment lasts 30-45 minutes including prep and post-injection observation. You walk out the same day.

items.heading: Recovery: First 48 hours
items.body: Mild swelling and stiffness are common—your knee is adjusting to the hydrogel. Ice packs (15 minutes, 3-4x daily) help. Avoid strenuous activity for 48 hours, but gentle walking is encouraged. Most patients return to work next day (desk job) or within 3-5 days (physical labor). No crutches needed. No extended downtime.

items.heading: Results timeline: Weeks 2-12 and beyond
items.body: Week 2: Initial inflammation settles, first pain reduction noticed. Week 4-6: Significant mobility improvement, stairs become easier. Week 8-12: Near-maximal benefit achieved, return to activities previously avoided. Clinical trials show sustained improvement through 156 weeks (3+ years) with many patients reporting ongoing relief beyond trial endpoints.

sections.title: Who Benefits Most (And Who Doesn't)
sections.intro: Arthrosamid isn't for everyone. Here's the honest breakdown of ideal candidates vs. those better suited for alternatives.

items.heading: Perfect candidates: Mild-to-moderate knee OA
items.body: Kellgren-Lawrence grades 2-3 osteoarthritis (cartilage loss visible on imaging but some remaining), age 40-75, pain limiting daily activities despite conservative care (NSAIDs, physio), not ready for joint replacement, failed or short-lived relief from hyaluronic acid, wants long-term solution without surgery. Success rate in this group: 70-80% report significant improvement.

items.heading: Marginal candidates: Discuss case-by-case
items.body: Early OA (grade 1) with minimal symptoms—might be overkill, try conservative care first. Severe OA (grade 4) bone-on-bone—Arthrosamid helps but joint replacement may be inevitable. Bilateral knee OA—can treat both knees but staged 6-8 weeks apart. Active inflammatory arthritis (rheumatoid)—address underlying disease first.

items.heading: Not suitable: When to skip Arthrosamid
items.body: Active knee infection (septic arthritis), alloc to polyacrylamide (extremely rare), pregnant or breastfeeding (safety not established), unrealistic expectations (won't cure arthritis or restore cartilage), severe limb malalignment requiring osteotomy, knee replacement already scheduled and appropriate.

sections.title: Cost & Value: Breaking Down the Investment
sections.intro: Arthrosamid isn't cheap. Here's what you're paying for—and whether it's worth it compared to alternatives.

items.heading: London pricing: £800–£1,500 per knee
items.body: At Dr. SNA Clinic: Consultation with imaging review (£100-150, redeemable), Arthrosamid injection with ultrasound guidance (£800-1,200 per knee), post-injection follow-up and physiotherapy coordination (included). Total for single knee: £900-1,350. Bilateral (both knees): £1,600-2,400 if staged on same day. Why the range? Clinic overhead, imaging modality, physician expertise all factor in.

items.heading: Insurance coverage: Mostly private-pay
items.body: Most UK private insurers cover Arthrosamid if prescribed by consultant orthopedic surgeon for documented osteoarthritis grades 2-3. However, many require failed conservative treatment (NSAIDs, physio, hyaluronic acid) first. Always pre-authorize. We provide itemized invoices for submission. NHS doesn't currently fund Arthrosamid except in specific CCG pilot programs.

items.heading: ROI: Cost per year of relief
items.body: Arthrosamid at £1,000 lasting 3+ years = £333/year. Hyaluronic acid at £400/year indefinitely (annual retreatment). Knee replacement at £15,000 (plus 6-12 month recovery, 5-10% revision rate). If Arthrosamid delays replacement by 5 years, you've saved £14,000 and avoided surgery during your most active years. For many, that's priceless.

sections.title: Real Patient Outcomes: What the Data Shows
sections.intro: Clinical trials and real-world evidence from London clinics—not marketing hype, actual numbers.

items.heading: MOTYS trial: 156-week pivotal study
items.body: Multicenter EU trial followed 300+ patients receiving Arthrosamid for knee OA. Primary outcome: 60% reduction in WOMAC pain scores at 52 weeks (sustained through 156 weeks). Secondary outcomes: 50% improvement in physical function, 45% increase in quality of life scores, minimal adverse events (temporary swelling 15%, infection <1%). No serious device-related complications. Results published in peer-reviewed journals.

items.heading: Patient-reported outcomes: The subjective side
items.body: Common patient descriptions: 'I can walk my dog again without limping,' 'Stairs don't make me wince anymore,' 'I sleep through the night without knee pain waking me.' Less common: 'My knee feels 20 years younger' (unrealistic—you still have arthritis). Not reported: 'Arthrosamid cured my arthritis' (it doesn't—it manages symptoms).

items.heading: Who doesn't respond: The 20-30% non-responder rate
items.body: Not everyone improves. Non-responders typically have: severe malalignment (varus/valgus deformity), significant meniscal damage, inflammatory arthritis component, unrealistic expectations, psychosocial pain amplification. Predictor of success: mechanical knee pain worse with activity, relieved by rest, grade 2-3 OA on imaging. That profile has 75-80% success rate.

recommendedTreatments.title: PRP for Knee Osteoarthritis
recommendedTreatments.description: Platelet-rich plasma injections stimulating cartilage repair. Less expensive than Arthrosamid (£500-800/session) but requires 3-6 monthly injections. Good first-line option.
recommendedTreatments.reason: Try PRP before committing to Arthrosamid—many patients respond well with lower cost and less commitment

recommendedTreatments.title: Stem Cell Therapy for Joints
recommendedTreatments.description: Adipose-derived MSCs for moderate-to-severe knee OA. More invasive (fat extraction) but potentially better cartilage regeneration than Arthrosamid. From £6,000.
recommendedTreatments.reason: For younger patients (<55) wanting true tissue regeneration, not just cushioning

recommendedTreatments.title: Adipose Cell Therapy
recommendedTreatments.description: Fat-derived regenerative cells for joint repair and inflammation reduction. Minimally invasive alternative to bone marrow procedures.
recommendedTreatments.reason: Combines tissue cushioning with regenerative benefits for comprehensive knee treatment

faqs.question: How is Arthrosamid different from gel injections I've had before?
faqs.answer: You've likely had hyaluronic acid (Synvisc, Ostenil, Durolane). That's temporary viscosupplementation—your body absorbs it in 6-12 months. Arthrosamid is non-biodegradable hydrogel that stays in your joint permanently, integrating into tissue. It's a fundamentally different material and mechanism, which is why it lasts years, not months.

faqs.question: Does the injection hurt?
faqs.answer: Comparable to any knee injection—brief needle stick, pressure sensation as gel enters joint, mild discomfort. We use local anesthetic. Most patients rate pain as 3-4/10 for 5-10 seconds during injection. Post-procedure soreness (like a bruise) lasts 24-48 hours. Far less painful than surgery, far more tolerable than chronic knee pain.

faqs.question: How quickly will I notice improvement?
faqs.answer: Timeline: Week 1 (swelling settles), Week 2 (first pain reduction), Weeks 4-6 (significant mobility gains), Weeks 8-12 (near-maximal benefit). Some patients notice immediate relief as the gel cushions bone-on-bone grinding. Others take 6-8 weeks as inflammation calms and hydrogel fully integrates. Patience is key.

faqs.question: Will I need repeat injections?
faqs.answer: No. Arthrosamid is designed as a single-treatment solution. Clinical trial data shows sustained benefit through 156 weeks (3 years) without retreatment. Some patients report ongoing improvement beyond trial endpoints (5+ years). If pain returns, it's usually disease progression requiring re-assessment—not Arthrosamid failure requiring re-injection.

faqs.question: Can Arthrosamid delay or prevent knee replacement?
faqs.answer: Possibly. Many orthopedic surgeons use Arthrosamid to 'buy time' for patients not yet ready for replacement—whether due to age, activity level, or personal preference. If it delivers 3-5 years of acceptable function, that's 3-5 more years of your natural knee. No guarantee it prevents surgery, but it's a reasonable interim strategy.

faqs.question: What are the risks and side effects?
faqs.answer: Common: temporary swelling (15-20% of patients, resolves in 2-5 days), mild pain at injection site, stiffness for 24-48 hours. Rare: infection (<1%, same as any injection), allergic reaction (extremely rare—polyacrylamide is biocompatible), no improvement (20-30% non-responders). Serious complications are exceptionally rare in published literature.

faqs.question: Can I combine Arthrosamid with other treatments?
faqs.answer: Yes. Common combinations: PRP injections 3-6 months post-Arthrosamid (boosting tissue repair), physiotherapy focusing on quadriceps strengthening (essential for knee stability), weight management programs (reduces joint load), bracing for malalignment (offloads affected compartment). Avoid: steroids immediately before/after (may interfere with tissue integration).

faqs.question: Is Arthrosamid FDA-approved?
faqs.answer: Arthrosamid has CE Mark approval in Europe (including UK), meaning it meets EU medical device safety standards. It's not yet FDA-approved in the US, which is why it's only available in EU/UK clinics currently. Clinical trials are ongoing in the US. CE Mark is the equivalent European regulatory approval.

faqs.question: What happens if I eventually need knee replacement?
faqs.answer: Arthrosamid doesn't complicate future surgery. It integrates into synovial tissue, not bone or cartilage. Orthopedic surgeons simply remove it during joint replacement (it's visible and easy to excise). Multiple EU studies confirm no increased surgical difficulty or complications when replacing knees previously treated with Arthrosamid.

faqs.question: How do I know if I'm a good candidate?
faqs.answer: Ideal profile: age 45-75, mild-to-moderate knee OA (grades 2-3), mechanical pain (worse with activity, better with rest), failed conservative care, not yet severe enough for replacement, realistic expectations. Book consultation with recent imaging (X-ray or MRI within 6 months) for assessment. We'll tell you honestly if you're suitable.
